question_details.title: Will the Artemis Accords have 54 signatories on April 1, 2025?
question_details.description: There are 53 signatories at the time of this question: Angola, Argentina, Armenia, Australia, Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, Chile, Colombia, the Republic of Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, India, Israel, Italy, Japan, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Mexico, Netherlands, New Zealand, Nigeria, Panama, Peru, Poland, the Republic of Korea, Romania, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Thailand, Ukraine, the United Arab Emirates, the United Kingdom, the United States, and Uruguay. [(source)](https://www.state.gov/bureau-of-oceans-and-international-environmental-and-scientific-affairs/artemis-accords)
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Artemis Accords has 54 (or more) signatories on April 1, 2025.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**US and Ukraine Expected to Sign Mineral Agreement After Historic Diplomatic Dispute**
According to Reuters, the US and Ukraine are expected to sign a 'mineral agreement' as early as April 4, after a historic diplomatic dispute. The agreement, which was initially set to be signed on March 28, was put on hold due to a public feud between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky over issues such as US security guarantees and their perception of Russian President Vladimir Putin. However, after the US imposed sanctions on Ukraine and Zelensky made a statement that can be seen as an apology, the agreement has regained its viability. Zelensky stated on Twitter, 'We truly value the support the US has provided to maintain Ukraine's sovereignty and independence.' He also expressed his willingness to sign the mineral agreement, saying, 'Ukraine is ready to sign the agreement in any form, and we see it as a step towards greater security and a more secure future.'
Original language: ko
Publish date: March 05, 2025 12:15 AM
Source:[mk.co.kr](https://www.mk.co.kr/news/world/11255654)

**New to Congress, Florida's Haridopolos leads debate on Artemis, moon and China**
New to Congress, Florida's Haridopolos leads debate on Artemis, moon and China. Haridopolos, who chairs the U.S. House Space and Aeronautics Subcommittee, said, 'We stand at a crossroads. The world is watching, and our competitors, like communist China, are racing to beat us there.' Witnesses, including former NASA official Dan Dumbacher and former executive secretary of the National Space Council Scott Pace, agreed that the moon should be the focus, but called for a quick revision to the current Artemis plan. Dumbacher warned against shifting the focus to Mars, saying, 'It's about doing the right thing at the right time.' Pace suggested considering alternatives for going from the Earth to the moon and back, such as buying heavy-lift services instead of developing the expensive and non-reusable Space Launch System rocket. The current Artemis program has many critics, including Trump's close advisor and SpaceX founder Elon Musk. To date, only the uncrewed Artemis I mission has made it to space, with the much-delayed crewed Artemis II mission slated for no later than April 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 04, 2025 06:19 PM
Source:[ArcaMax](https://www.arcamax.com/currentnews/newsheadlines/s-3621635)

**The New Era of Space Exploration: A Global Competition**
The space industry is no longer just a scientific frontier, but a pillar of global economic growth and security. The annual report on information security policy highlights the intense and strategic competition in space, with investments of billions of dollars, geopolitical challenges, and the rise of new actors. The report notes that the space industry is now a major driver of economic growth, with a market value of $570 billion in 2023, a 7.4% increase from the previous year. The US leads the way, with a spending of $73 billion, followed by China with $14 billion. The report also highlights the growing presence of private actors, such as SpaceX, which has launched 134 missions in 2024, more than all other launchers combined. The Starlink constellation, also developed by SpaceX, has nearly 7,000 satellites in orbit, making it the largest satellite network in the world. However, the report also notes the growing problem of space debris, with over 36,000 objects in orbit, including 10,000 active payloads. The report also discusses the new era of space exploration, with the Artemis program aiming to return humans to the Moon by 2027, and the International Lunar Research Station (ILRS) initiative, a joint project between Russia and China, aiming to establish a human presence on the Moon by 2035. 
Original language: it
Publish date: March 04, 2025 02:11 PM
Source:[Formiche.net](https://formiche.net/2025/03/corsa-alla-luna-la-sfida-arriva-da-mosca-e-pechino-lintelligence-fa-il-punto-sullo-spazio/)

**Mariana Tragedy Agreement Reaches 17 Signatures**
Two new municipalities, Santa Cruz do Escalvado and Rio Doce, have joined the list of signatories to the Mariana tragedy agreement, bringing the total number of signatories to 17. Eight other cities have already sent the necessary documentation for signature. If confirmed, 23 of the 41 affected cities will join the agreement negotiated by governments and mining companies and approved by the STF (Supremo Tribunal Federal) in November last year. The proposal provides for the direct distribution of R$ 6.1 billion to municipalities and payment over 20 years. Juliano Duarte, mayor of Mariana, the city most affected by the disaster, said he will not sign the agreement, questioning the values offered and the payment period. He will continue with the process in England, which is also the target of an action in the STF by the Ibram (Instituto Brasileiro de Mineração), which questions the legitimacy of Brazilian municipalities being parties to processes abroad. 'I will not sign the agreement, it's not worth it,' said Juliano Duarte. 'The values offered are not enough, and the payment period is too long.' 
Original language: pt
Publish date: March 04, 2025 12:08 PM

**State Duma Approves Agreement to Postpone Payments Under Russian-Belarusian Intergovernmental Agreements**
The State Duma has approved a law to ratify an agreement to postpone payments under Russian-Belarusian intergovernmental agreements. The agreement, signed on April 25, and the protocol, signed on July 11, last year, provide for a payment delay. According to Deputy Minister of Finance of the Russian Federation, Vladimir Kolychev, 'The agreement and protocol were signed to reduce the payment burden on the budget of the Republic of Belarus in terms of paying off and servicing debt obligations to the Russian Federation in 2024.' Kolychev noted that the agreement and protocol were signed in accordance with the President of Russia's instruction on the President of Belarus's corresponding appeal. 'The agreements provide for the postponement of payments to pay off the principal debt from April 1, 2024, to December 31, 2024, and interest payments from July 1 to December 31, 2024, to the period 2031-2036. The total amount of payments to be postponed is approximately $800 million in dollar equivalent,' Kolychev clarified.

**New Taipei City Dual Recall: 12 Physical Signature Stations Announced**
The second stage of the dual recall of New Taipei City Councilor Zheng Zhengqian and suspended Mayor Gao Hong'an has begun, with 12 physical signature stations announced. The stations include the Democratic Progressive Party's New Taipei City branch and 9 city councilor service centers, as well as the service centers of Legislator Ke Jianming and law professor Lin Zhijie. Lin Zhijie's service center was the first to open on March 5 from 6pm to 10pm, and he also encouraged volunteers to participate in the signature drive. According to leader Dai Zhenbo, the first stage of the proposal signature drive saw 70,000 signatures, with 7,000 for each of the two individuals. The second stage aims for 5,000 signatures each, totaling 10,000 signatures. The deadline for the second stage is April 6, and the organizers hope to complete the 10,000 signatures by mid-to-late April. 'We will not give up, we will not give in,' Dai Zhenbo said. 'We will work hard to reach our goal of 10,000 signatures and bring justice to the people of New Taipei City.'
Original language: zh
Publish date: March 04, 2025 07:05 AM

**World Monuments Fund Warns of Potential Damage to the Moon from Space Tourism**
The World Monuments Fund (WMF) has included the Moon in its list of sites that may be damaged due to unregulated space tourism, according to The New York Times. The organization is concerned about the potential destruction of over 90 important sites on the Moon, including the Tranquility Base (База Спокойствия), where Neil Armstrong first stepped on the lunar surface. The WMF is a international non-profit organization that works to preserve cultural heritage around the world. They are concerned that scientific expeditions and space tourism may impact the state of the Moon's surface, including items left on the surface such as a golden olive branch and 125 miniature sculptures delivered by SpaceX. The WMF notes that international cooperation is necessary to protect the Moon, but the Artemis Accords, signed by over 50 countries in 2020, have limited impact due to the lack of signature from major space-faring nations such as the US, Russia, and China. Some experts argue that the threats to the Moon are not as pressing, as many scientific missions are directed away from previous landing sites, and space tourism does not currently impact these historic areas. 'It is a response to the growing interest in space travel and the problems associated with space debris,' said the WMF. 'We need international cooperation to protect the Moon,' they added.

**New Negotiations on International Treaty to Combat Plastic Pollution**
The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has announced that new negotiations for an international treaty to combat plastic pollution will take place from August 5 to 14 in Geneva, Switzerland. This comes after a previous round of talks in Busan, South Korea, in December ended without an agreement. Over 170 countries participated in the discussions. According to the UN, 400 million tons of plastic waste are produced annually, and this number is increasing. In March 2022, nearly 200 UN member states agreed to come up with concrete measures by the end of 2024. The negotiations have been ongoing for 10 years. The announcement follows the agreement on funding to combat biodiversity loss, which was reached in Rome last Thursday.
Original language: nl
Publish date: March 04, 2025 12:05 AM
Source:[Het Nieuwsblad](https://www.nieuwsblad.be/cnt/dmf20250304_00916680)

**SpaceX Prepares for 8th Starship Rocket Test Flight: How to Watch**
SpaceX is preparing for its eighth Starship rocket test flight, which will largely be a do-over of the seventh test flight that ended in a disintegration over the Caribbean. The company has made changes to the vehicle, including altering propellant temperatures and thrust levels, adding more vents to the attic section, and a system to purge the area of propellants. The flight aims to come to a less explosive conclusion. Starship will test a new system that shoots out dummy satellites, and will also try to catch its booster. The company is looking to improve the reliability of the rocket and plans to receive approval from the Federal Aviation Administration for up to 25 flights this year. NASA is planning to use a version of Starship to take astronauts to the moon during its Artemis III mission, currently scheduled for 2027.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 03, 2025 09:58 PM
Source:[The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/03/science/spacex-starship-launch.html)

**SpaceX receive the all clear to launch Starship's eighth test flight**
SpaceX has received regulatory approval to launch the eighth test flight of its Starship rocket, which will target objectives not reached during its last trial. The flight will aim to deploy a payload of 10 mock-up Starlink internet satellites and splash down in the Indian Ocean. The company has made several hardware and operational changes to increase the reliability of the upper-stage, which failed to deploy the payload during the seventh flight test. The Starship rocket is designed to send astronauts to the Moon and beyond, and will play a key role in NASA's Artemis III mission in 2026. The launch is expected to last just over an hour and will be broadcast live on the official SpaceX website and ABC digital coverage.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 03, 2025 07:10 PM
Source:[Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-03-04/musk-spacex-starship-eighth-test-flight-explainer-live/104978862)

**Artemis Agreement Signatories Commit To Continued Openness And Transparency In Space Endeavours - UrduPoint**
The signatories of the Artemis Agreements have reaffirmed their commitment to maintaining openness and transparency in their space-related activities and plans. The agreements, launched in 2020, aim to guide civil space exploration and its use in the 21st century. As of January 2025, 53 countries have signed the agreements, including the UAE, Australia, and the US. The signatories have agreed to focus on sustainability in 2025, particularly in areas such as debris mitigation and management of lunar surface and orbital debris. They have also proposed strengthening capacity-building workshops in specific regional areas to involve emerging space actors in discussions about safe and sustainable space operations. The signatories have committed to following the principles designed to promote safe, sustainable, and transparent space activities, including transparency in publishing information, national space policies and plans, and exchanging scientific data.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 12, 2025 09:27 PM
Source:[UrduPoint](https://www.urdupoint.com/en/middle-east/artemis-agreement-signatories-commit-to-conti-1923188.html)

**Finland Joins 'Artemis Accords' as 53rd Country, Emphasizing International Cooperation in Space Research**
Finland has become the 53rd country to join the 'Artemis Accords', a set of agreements that define best practices for safe and sustainable space research. Finland signed the accords on January 21, 2025, during the Winter Space Seminar 2025 at Aalto University in Espoo, Finland. 'Today, Finland joins the community of countries that want to freely exchange scientific data, work safely, and preserve the space environment for the Artemis generation,' said NASA Deputy Administrator Jim Freiday. Finnish Economy Minister Ville Rüdman signed the agreement on behalf of Finland, saying, 'Our goal is for this cooperation to open up opportunities for the Finnish space sector in a new era of space research and the Artemis program.' The Finnish Ministry of Economic Affairs emphasized that by signing the non-binding agreement, the country continues to consider the UN as the primary forum for developing international space law and will comply with such laws in its space activities. Finland's accession follows a record 19 countries signing the Artemis Accords in 2024. NASA and the US State Department attribute the surge to growing recognition of the value of the accords as a forum for discussing space security and sustainability issues. The Artemis Accords were initiated in 2020 during the first Trump administration, when the US and seven other countries signed them. However, some industry representatives question whether the new Trump administration will maintain the same level of support for the accords, given its 'America First' philosophy. Experts are divided on the role of international cooperation, including the Artemis Accords, in the new Trump administration. While Lori Garver, former NASA Deputy Administrator under Obama, is skeptical about the accords' future, Scott Pace, Executive Secretary of the National Space Council in the first Trump administration, believes that international interaction will remain an important part of policy, as it is tied to broader national interests.
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 22, 2025 04:06 PM

**Finland signs on to Artemis Accords**
Finland has become the 53rd nation to join NASA's Artemis Accords, a global agreement for responsible manned exploration of the moon. The signing took place during the Winter Satellite Workshop in Espoo, Finland, where Economic Affairs Minister Wille Rydman stated, 'The signing of the Artemis Accords is in line with Finland's newly updated space strategy that highlights the importance of international cooperation and of strengthening partnerships with the United States and other allies.' The Artemis Accords aim to promote best practices and responsible space exploration behavior, and Finland looks forward to participating in the next chapter of discovery and benefiting from the opportunities it presents.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 22, 2025 12:07 PM
Source:[upi.com](https://www.upi.com/Science_News/2025/01/22/Finland-Artemis-Accords-NASA/3751737546025/)

**Finland Becomes 53rd Nation To Sign Artemis Accords**
Finland has signed the Artemis Accords, joining 52 other nations in committing to the safe and responsible exploration of space. Finland's minister of economic affairs, Wille Rydman, signed the accords at a ceremony in Espoo, Finland. This move builds on Finland's existing collaboration with NASA, including a contribution to the Intuitive Machines-2 delivery to the Moon, which will feature a lunar LTE/4G communications system developed by Nokia. The Artemis Accords promote the beneficial use of space for humanity, and are grounded in the Outer Space Treaty and other agreements. As stated by the principles of the Artemis Accords, signatory nations will 'publicly release scientific data' and adhere to 'best practices for responsible behavior'.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 22, 2025 11:38 AM
Source:[rttnews.com](https://www.rttnews.com/3504983/finland-becomes-53rd-nation-to-sign-artemis-accords.aspx)

**Finland joins Artemis Accords to boost space cooperation**
Finland has officially joined the Artemis Accords, becoming the 53rd nation to commit to peaceful and cooperative space exploration. Wille Rydman, Finland’s Minister of Economic Affairs, signed the accords, highlighting Finland’s contributions to space technology and research. The Artemis Accords outline principles for peaceful and transparent space exploration, including the Moon and other celestial bodies. Finland's expertise in science and technology, particularly in navigation and Earth observation, makes it a valuable partner for NASA. The signing took place during the Winter Satellite Workshop 2025 in Espoo, where Finland showcased its space capabilities and commitment to fostering ethical and sustainable exploration.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 22, 2025 07:30 AM
Source:[helsinkitimes.fi](https://www.helsinkitimes.fi/world-int/26002-finland-joins-artemis-accords-to-boost-space-cooperation.html)

**Finland becomes 53rd country to join the Artemis Accords for moon exploration**
Finland has become the 53rd country to join the Artemis Accords, a set of principles and guidelines for peaceful and cooperative international space exploration. The signing ceremony took place on January 21, 2025, at the Winter Satellite Workshop 2025 in Espoo, Finland. According to Finland's Minister of Economic Affairs, Wille Rydman, 'Finland has been part of the space exploration community for decades with Finnish companies and research institutes producing many innovations and technologies.' Rydman added that the Artemis Accords will strengthen Finland's partnership with the United States and other allies, opening up opportunities for the Finnish space sector. NASA Associate Administrator Jim Free stated, 'Today, Finland is joining a community of nations that want to share scientific data freely, operate safely, and preserve the space environment for the Artemis Generation.' The Artemis Accords were founded in October 2020 and have since gained international signatories, including Liechtenstein, Thailand, Panama, and Austria.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 22, 2025 04:26 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/finland-becomes-53rd-country-join-220000379.html)

**Finland Signs Artemis Accords Amidst Uncertainty**
Finland signed the Artemis Accords on January 21, becoming the first country to do so this year amidst questions about the future of the agreement under the new Trump administration. According to NASA, Finland signed the agreements, which define best practices for safe and sustainable space exploration, during the 2025 Winter Satellite Workshop at Aalto University in Espoo, Finland. 'Finland signed the Artemis Accords,' NASA said in a statement. Finland's move comes as the country continues to push forward with its space exploration efforts.

**Finland signs Artemis Accords**
Finland signed the Artemis Accords on Tuesday in Otaniemi, Espoo, with Minister of Economic Affairs Wille Rydman signing on behalf of Finland. The Artemis Accords, established by NASA and the US Department of State, aim to boost NASA's Artemis Program by specifying common rules for civil exploration and use of the Moon, Mars, comets, and asteroids for peaceful purposes. Rydman stated, 'Finland has been part of the space exploration community for decades, and with the Artemis Accords, we will strengthen our partnership with the United States and other allies, opening up opportunities for the Finnish space sector in the new era of space exploration and the Artemis Program.' Finland continues to consider the United Nations the primary forum for international space law and complies with international law in its space activities. The signing ceremony was held in connection with the Winter Satellite Workshop, the largest New Space event in Scandinavia and the Baltic countries, with over 1,000 participants.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 22, 2025 12:52 AM
Source:[dailyfinland.fi](https://www.dailyfinland.fi/national/41435/Finland-signs-Artemis-Accords)

**Finland Signs Artemis Accords, Strengthening International Cooperation in Space Exploration**
On January 21, 2025, Finnish Minister of Economic Affairs Wille Rydman signed the Artemis Accords at Otaniemi, Espoo, strengthening the country's commitment to international cooperation in space exploration. The Artemis Accords, established by NASA and the US Department of State, aim to promote NASA's Artemis program, which aims to explore the Moon, Mars, comets, and asteroids for peaceful purposes. Rydman stated, 'Finland has been part of the space exploration community for decades, with Finnish companies and research institutions developing many innovations and technologies. With the Artemis Accords, we will strengthen our partnership with the United States and other allies. Our goal is for this cooperation to open up new opportunities for the Finnish space sector in the new era of space exploration and the Artemis program.' The signing ceremony was held during the Winter Satellite Workshop, a major event for the Finnish space sector that brought together over 1,000 participants. This workshop is considered the largest event dedicated to New Space in Scandinavia and the Baltic countries, further solidifying Finland's role as a leader in space technology development. With this signing, Finland positions itself as a strategic partner in international cooperation for space exploration, opening up new prospects for the future of the national space sector.
Original language: it
Publish date: January 21, 2025 10:33 PM
Source:[meteoweb.eu](https://www.meteoweb.eu/2025/01/paese-firma-artemis-accords-cooperazione-spaziale/1001734713/)

**NASA Welcomes Finland as Newest Artemis Accords Signatory - NASA**
NASA welcomed Finland as the 53rd nation to sign the Artemis Accords, a set of principles promoting the safe and responsible exploration of space that benefits humanity. According to NASA Associate Administrator Jim Free, 'Today, Finland is joining a community of nations that want to share scientific data freely, operate safely, and preserve the space environment for the Artemis Generation.' Finland's minister of economic affairs, Wille Rydman, signed the Artemis Accords, highlighting the importance of international cooperation and strengthening partnerships with the United States and other allies. Finland has a long history of collaboration with NASA, including contributing to the upcoming Intuitive Machines-2 delivery to the Moon and providing instruments for the Curiosity Rover on Mars.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 21, 2025 04:40 PM
Source:[NASA](https://www.nasa.gov/news-release/nasa-welcomes-finland-as-newest-artemis-accords-signatory/)

**NASA welcomes Finland as the newest Artemis Accords signatory**
NASA welcomed Finland as the 53rd nation to sign the Artemis Accords, a set of principles promoting the safe and responsible exploration of space that benefits humanity. According to NASA Associate Administrator Jim Free, 'Today, Finland is joining a community of nations that want to share scientific data freely, operate safely, and preserve the space environment for the Artemis Generation.' Finland's minister of economic affairs, Wille Rydman, signed the Artemis Accords, stating, 'The signing of the Artemis Accords is in line with Finland’s newly updated space strategy that highlights the importance of international cooperation and of strengthening partnerships with the Unites States and other allies.' NASA and Finland have a long history of collaboration, including Finland's contribution to the upcoming Intuitive Machines-2 delivery to the Moon and the Finnish Meteorological Institute's provision of instruments for the Environmental Monitoring Station instrument suite aboard the Curiosity Rover on Mars.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 21, 2025 03:00 PM
Source:[satnews.com](https://news.satnews.com/2025/01/21/nasa-welcomes-finland-as-the-newest-artemis-accords-signatory/)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To establish an initial probability, I will consider historical growth rates and the context of international agreements similar to the Artemis Accords. Agreements focused on international space cooperation, like the Artemis Accords, are often viewed favorably as they promote peaceful exploration and can drive economic and scientific advancements. Historically, incremental growth in signatories is common, especially if the conditions of joining are favorable or if there's a global event or trend supporting it. On average, agreements related to international cooperation may see a new signatory every few months, particularly if they've been previously trending upwards and there's a focus on them at certain international forums. Given the current count of 53 signatories, estimating a 70% base probability that one additional country will join by April 1, 2025, seems reasonable.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Increased Global Interest in Space Exploration
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The recent surge in interest regarding space exploration and missions, spurred by both governmental and private sector initiatives, increases the likelihood of additional nations wanting to align with the Artemis Accords. With the successes of recent missions and ongoing projects, more countries seek partnerships to bolster their own space capabilities.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Existing Diplomatic Engagement
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Countries that are in active dialogue with existing signatories or have shown a prior interest in space endeavors are more likely to join. Continuous diplomatic engagement promotes collaborative environments, which often leads to agreements like the Artemis Accords. The existing diplomatic relationships with potential signatories heighten the chance of another country joining.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Geopolitical Stability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The absence of substantial geopolitical tensions affecting international cooperative agreements like the Artemis Accords in the past months contributes to a stable environment conducive to new signatories. Unless significant geopolitical events arise, this stability is a supporting factor.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news indicates that space-related agreements continue to be a focal point in diplomatic engagements, as seen with high-level discussions like the US and Ukraine's 'mineral agreement'. Additionally, ongoing debates in the US Congress emphasize the strategic importance of the Artemis program and space endeavors, reflecting continued interest and potential alignment efforts by countries to join space-related frameworks like the Artemis Accords. Furthermore, the growing recognition of the space industry as a significant economic and strategic frontier reinforces the motivation for countries to participate in international agreements such as the Artemis Accords to leverage opportunities in space exploration.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: No new countries announced imminent intentions to join the Artemis Accords, and the increase in complexity of geopolitical relations, exemplified by the US-Ukraine diplomatic situation, could complicate the climate for international agreements. The presence of alternative international partnerships, such as the ILRS initiative by Russia and China, might also act as a competing incentive against joining the Artemis Accords.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Based on historical data, the Artemis Accords have rapidly gained signatories since their inception, with 53 signatories currently listed. Given the trend of increasing global cooperation in space exploration and the importance of the Accords in promoting peaceful and cooperative use of space, an increase in signatories is historically probable. Previously, similar international agreements have seen new signatories at a rate of 1-4 countries per year. Taking this into account, and noting that it is early in the year, I estimate an initial probability of 50% for the Accords gaining at least one new signatory by April 1, 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Developments in Space Cooperation
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent global developments have shown an increasing trend towards international cooperation in space, especially among emerging space nations. This trend positively influences the probability that additional countries will join the Accords to align with international norms and practices.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Diplomatic Efforts of Current Signatories
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Many current signatories are influential nations that often engage in diplomatic efforts to encourage other countries to join international agreements. This diplomatic effort increases the probability of new signatories by leveraging existing alliances and cooperative relationships.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Competition from Other International Frameworks
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There is competition from other international space agreements that might align more closely with the strategic interests of some non-signatory countries. This competitive landscape can reduce the likelihood of additional countries joining the Artemis Accords.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Finland recently became the 53rd signatory to the Artemis Accords, indicating ongoing international interest and momentum in joining the Accords. The recent reaffirmation of commitment by current signatories to transparency and cooperation suggests a conducive environment for additional countries to join. This aligns with the increasing diplomatic efforts and international cooperation around space exploration.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: None of the news articles suggest significant challenges or diplomatic barriers preventing additional countries from joining the Artemis Accords. No major geopolitical conflicts or setbacks within the Accords framework that would directly deter new signatories were reported.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: The Artemis Accords have been gaining signatories steadily since their inception in 2020. Previous years have shown a consistent increase in the number of countries joining the agreement. Considering this historical trend, we can establish a base rate. Over the past year, the accords added several new members, indicating a positive trend towards further international collaboration in space exploration. Given there are 53 signatories already, adding one more is a reasonable expectation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Global Interest in Space Exploration
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There is a growing interest globally in space exploration, driven by technological advances and the strategic importance of space. This trend encourages countries to join international frameworks like the Artemis Accords to ensure they're part of future collaborative space efforts.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Bilateral and Multilateral Diplomacy
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Ongoing diplomatic efforts between the United States and other nations often pave the way for states to sign the Artemis Accords. The US plays a key role in promoting the accords as part of its foreign policy related to space.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Stability and International Relations

summary: After reviewing the experts' predictions across two phases, the consensus is that there is a high likelihood of the Artemis Accords gaining at least one more signatory by April 1, 2025. Initial probabilities ranged from 25% to 90%, with most experts estimating a probability between 60% and 90%. Factors such as increased global interest in space exploration, diplomatic efforts by current signatories, and the strategic appeal of the Artemis Accords were seen as strong positive influences. However, challenges such as geopolitical tensions, competing international frameworks, and the lack of imminent announcements of new signatories were noted. Despite these challenges, most experts maintained or slightly adjusted their probabilities after evaluating recent news, resulting in final probabilities predominantly in the range of 65% to 90%.
